Award.AwardTitle: Travel Grant for Attending 31st IEEE Symposium on Reliable Distributed Systems (SRDS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project supports travel grants to US students and junior faculty to participate in the 31st IEEE Symposium on Reliable Distributed Systems (SRDS)(http://web.mst.edu/~cswebdb/srds2012/)being held in Irvine, CA, USA, October 8-11, 2012. This is a high quality technical conference for researchers and practitioners who are interested in reliability, security, availability, privacy, and safety of distributed systems. It typically attracts 100-125 papers, 25-30 accepted papers, and 75 to 100 attendees. In addition, the conference also has workshops and PhD forum activities. The middle-sized nature of this conference makes it suitable for extended technical discussions among participants. Being held in the US to enable participants from the US to learn about the computing profession and research environment around the world will likely to have an enriching effect on the fledgling research careers of the awardees and start off discussions between them and the academic and industrial participants from US, Europe and Asia in general.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant helped 19 US students to attend 31st IEEE International Symposium on Reliable Distributed Systems (IEEE SRDS) held in Irvine, California. This is one of the flagship conference in the area of reliable distributed systems sponsored by IEEE. The conference attracted over 100 participants from all over the world. The conference had associated workshops, a panel and a poster session other than several regular research sessions. 

These students attended SRDS to learn the current state of the art in distributed systems reliability, sensor networks, cyber physical systems, secuity, etc. Most of them presented their research results in conference sessions, or in a poster session or in workshops. They have also participated in a panel related to cyber physical system. Thus, these students got a unique opportunity to discuss research ideas with many research leaders from academia, industry and government labs in the broad area of distributed systems reliability. 

Te grant helped these US students in broadening their knolwedge with international perspective of science, engineering and technology. Students were also able to discuss and interact with many other students who came from many other countries. Thus, this also provided an opportunity to them to learn not only scietific discoveries, but also associated cultural and social aspect.
